title.narrative: Young Palestinians; the Light in the Midst of Darkness

description.narrative: Following is an account to the direct beneficiaries of the project: 14 young Palestinians who will serve as youth workers. 500 people involved in the 4 community projects with a project in southern WB, another in northern WB, a third in central West Bank and a 4th in the Jordan valley. 200 people involved in the 6 debates. 150 participants of the conference Representatives of 20 private businesses that include big businesses such as Palestinian telecommunication, Padico, Coka Cola and small businesses that will be targeted by the projects team and the researcher. 20 representatives of political parties, students unions, PLC (independent and those who belong to political parties) 60 fresh graduates trained at a number of businesses and get career opportunities.

Outputs to fulfill outcome 1.1. Improved PYALARAs, young Palestinians and stakeholders capacities to advance young Palestinians socio-economic position
Empowered and well-trained Pyalaras staff, young Palestinians, representatives of political parties and students unions. Number of training of trainers seminars conducted (1.1) - 6 training workshops conducted. Number of trainers awarded completion certificates (1.1)- 14 young Palestinian participants awarded completion certificates. Number of curricula used (1.2) - One curricula on leadership and debating developed Number of participants awarded completion participation, good governance and democracy training certificates (1.2) - 30 young Palestinians Number of leadership development programmes developed (1.3) - 2 programmes developed Number of leadership development participants awarded completion certificates (1.3) - 30 young Palestinians. Number of youth services (1.4) - 1 employment service provided for 30 fresh graduates. Number of networks of young leaders initiated or supported (1.4) - 2 networks formed Number of senior leaders in networks (1.4) - 12 senior leaders
Outputs to fulfill outcome 2.1. Enhanced young Palestinians role and representation in the decision making process Number of youth in the network (2.1) - 60 / 250 young Palestinians are involved in the network. Number of exchange visits (2.1) - 15 visits Number of trainers awarded ToT completion certificates (2.2) - 40 young Palestinians Number of youth reached by leadership programs (2.2) - 700 young Palestinians Number of surveys and reports produces (2.3) - 1 survey and 4 reports produced Number of people reached by campaigns and public debates (2.4) - 850/1000/1250 persons involved in the debates, conference and community projects
Outputs to fulfill outcome 3.1. Influencing the Palestinian governments policy towards nepotism along with influencing political agendas of political parties and private sector through multi stakeholders dialogue Palestinian government and political parties more aware of the socio-economic position of young Palestinians Number of guidance and coaching trajectories implemented (3.1) - 6 guidance and coaching trajectories implemented Number of events held (like round tables etc) (3.1) - 10 events took place.

Statistics issued by Palestinian Central Bureau of Statistics for the 2nd of 2014 stipulate that the unemployment rate in the West Bank has reached 19.1% whereas in Gaza it has reached 46.4%. The highest unemployment rate was 42.8% among youth aged 20-24 years. For years of schooling, the highest unemployment rate among females with 13 years of schooling or more was 52.4%. The public sector employs 22.4% of those in employment with 62.6% by the private sectors, 11.9% in Israel and the settlements and 3% in other sectors. In regard to average daily wage for a wage employee is (96.7 NIS “$24.7” in public sector, with 71.4 NIS “$19.8” in private sectors and with 184.3 NIS “$51.2” in Israel and settlement.
In order to improve the socioeconomic situation of young Palestinians, PYALARA has initiated its MANARAT project which has been funded by SPARK since January 1, 2013. The project contributes to improving the socio- economic position of young Palestinians through capacity building, advocacy campaigning and policy change. We have managed over the past year to create well informed cadres of young Palestinians who were involved in scores of capacity building sessions. They served as youth workers and young Palestinian leaders. They managed to raise awareness of their peers and community members on issues related to the socioeconomic situation and managed to brainstorm major issues that hinder young Palestinians engagement and participation in the decision Making process. The project also succeeded in bridging the gap between young Palestinians and Palestinian officials and decision makers, political parties and private businesses to a certain extent through encounters and dialogues to influence them place youth issues on their agendas. The importance of the project lies in its tendency to change policies in favor of young Palestinians rather than opening job opportunities.
Following the implementation of the project over the past year, the different sectors of the Palestinian society become aware of MANARAT project as follows: MANARAT is well known inside Palestinian universities. University students who took part in the project in addition to those involved in YEP training promoted the project amongst their peers in the different Palestinian universities and colleges that include (Abu Deis university, Al-Quds Open University, Khdouri technical school, An-Najah university and Hebron university). Political parties become more aware of MANARA and many of political parties representatives expressed their interest in being involved in the project activities and in the debates that will be implemented as part of the project. Civil society organizations become more aware of the project. This was expressed through our encounters with a number of representatives of CBOs and NGOs. It is worth noting that we cooperated with around 40 organizations and youth centers so far. Private businesses become aware of the project and its activities.
Following the 55 workshops that were carried out in the different Palestinian governorates to identify major issues that hinder young Palestinians from improving their socio-economic situation which they identified as retirement age, nepotism and lack of young Palestinians capacities and practical experience and following the two national meetings that were carried out in Hebron and Nablus which aimed at discussing the above issues with decision makers that include: Mr. Mohammad Shaheen and Dr. Mohamad Amr from Al-Quds university, Mr. Mohammad Abu Rahma and Mr. Badr Amarneh, legal consultants, and Mr. Mazin Laham and Mr. Said Shehad from Anti corruption commission, young Palestinians stressed that the emphasis should be directed towards nepotism and retirement age.
Following such activities, a number of meetings were conducted with representatives of the four major Palestinian political parties. A meeting was conducted with Mr. Mahmoud Aloul, Fatah member; Mr. Qais Abdel-Karim, member of the Democratic front; Ms. Kahlida Jarar, member of the popular front and Mr. Hasan Yousef, member of Hamas. The goal of such meetings was two-fold: first, to get their support to the projects themes (nepotism and retirement age) and secondly to include such issues and themes on their agendas. We got the support of the different political parties apart from Hamas who were reluctant to cooperate for security reasons.
The project was crowned by a conference that PYALARA organized on November 4, 2014 in Ramallah under the title “Towards a national campaign to combat nepotism in Palestine”. The conference was attended by a number of decision makers that include: Dr. Mohammad Shtayyeh, Director of Palestinian Economic Council for Research and DevelopmentPECDAR, Dr. Samir Hleileh, the Chief Executive Officer of Palestine Development and Investment Ltd. (PADICO), Mr. Amar Akr, the Palestine Telecom Group CEO, Mr. Mosa Abu Zeid, Director General of Personnel Council, Dr. Sabri Saidam, a lecturer at BirZeit university and an expert in telecommunications and information technology, Mr. Abdel Muneim Wahdan, member of mobilization and organization unit/ Fatah party and Mrs. Khalideh Jarrar, Popular Front for the Liberation of Palestine (PFLP) and many other guests. There was a consensus amongst the participants on the importance of combating nepotism which is a highly spread phenomenon inside the Palestinian society. The conferences yielded in forming a committee that would approach the Palestinian prime minister Mr. Rami Al-Hamdallah to declare 2015 as a year of combating nepotism and urged the government to adopt an action plan to fulfill such a purpose.

organisation.narrative: The Palestinian Youth Association for Leadership and Rights Activation

mailing-address.narrative: The Palestinian Youth Association for Leadership and Rights Activation P.O. Box RAMALLAH Palestijns Bezette Gebieden
